content.description:
Follow the line of bolts up the center of the buttress past numerous weird cruxes. There are often good rests. An intermediate anchor at 90' is a sensible place to stop, but you can continue on at 5.9+ through an exposed headwall. While the "real" climbing ends at the first anchor, the next stretch is pretty fun and makes for a long pitch.This will require two ropes or two lowers.

 Alternatively, you can lower from a single bolt & quicklink at a point where things get low angle. From here, with backcleaning, you can lower off with a 70m rope, but it's probably a bad idea to use just one bolt as your anchor.
content.protection: At least 18 draws if you go all the way.  A dozen or so to the first anchor.

content.description:
Easy, Hard, or Impossible. The Hell Sloper would be, could be a Sedona's hardest but its far beyond current capabilities. On the Moon maybe, Mars for sure not. Perfect beater for anyone looking for sik aid practice. Great oblique workout! 

  Open to anyone who is willing. Expect steep sand and slopers. Maintenance mandatory on the classic start. Low milage.
content.location: Just to the climbers right of 'Red Lizard'

content.description: This is a surprisingly good warm up loaded with large pockets and big moves in between them. A little Sedona style mantle at the top reminds you where you are...
content.protection: Bolts to two Fixe ring anchors up high.
content.location: In the obvious pocketed gulley to the north of Red Lizard.  This route is the right most of 5 different routes.

content.description: "He never sleeps, the judge. He is dancing, dancing. He says that he will never die." Maybe your warm up for Red Lizard? The crux includes good tips lie-backing up to and around a roof. Start up easy blocky ledges and clip two bolts to get to the base of the corner. Sling a sturdy juni-pine as an anchor at the top.
content.protection: 2 bolts single purple metolius, .2, .3, .4, .5, #1extra .3-.5 will help give you some variety
content.location: Hike straight up to Red Lizard from the cemetery, Once at the base, hug the right side of the Red Lizard cliff  heading towards the Hell Sloper project. Continue a couple 100 feet until a gully is reached. Cross the gully and slightly up hill, following the path of least resistance until you're against the cliff on the other side. Hike uphill for a couple minutes until you see the obvious low angle lie-back corner of Blood Meridian. Only about 10 minutes or less from the base of Red Lizard.

content.description: This area is approached from the Sedona Cemetery.  It is home to Red Lizard, a single climb that is totally worth the trip up to the wall.  Supposedly the gully to the left of Red Lizard also has some routes.
